I’m looking at the board after our last move. Our snake (ID 1) now has its head at (6,2) and a body segment at (5,2). We’ve already gotten an apple (the one that was at (6,2) from the RIGHT move) so we’re looking for our next target. The remaining apples are at:
 • (1, 3)
 • (1, 9)
 • (3, 8)
 • (3, 1)
 • (4, 8)

Calculating Manhattan distances from our head (6,2), the closest apple is (3,1):
 Distance = |6–3| + |2–1| = 3 + 1 = 4.

Our enemy snake (#2) is at (5,6), which is not an immediate threat given its distance. Since our snake is short (head at (6,2) and tail at (5,2)), we have flexibility and can safely move without risking a self-collision if we don’t double back onto our body (keeping in mind that if we don’t pick up an apple a move’s tail will be removed).

To approach the apple at (3,1), we can either head LEFT or DOWN:
 • Moving LEFT would put our head at (5,2), which is currently our tail’s location. That square is safe because if we don’t eat an apple, our tail will vacate that location immediately.
 • Alternatively, moving DOWN brings our head to (6,1). Then the apple (3,1) lies directly to our left, and we can work our way there with subsequent moves.

Both choices get us closer, but moving DOWN aligns our y-coordinate with the apple (both at y = 1), setting us up nicely to then move left and claim it. This also avoids any ambiguity with following our own body.

Thus, my plan is to move DOWN next, with the longer-term strategy of turning LEFT over the coming moves until we reach (3,1).

Looking at our current board, our snake’s head is at (5,6) and its body occupies [(4,6), (4,5), (5,5), (5,4), (5,3), (5,2)]. The apples on the board are at (1,3), (9,9), (8,7), (4,0), and (3,9). Of these, the nearest in Manhattan distance appears to be the apple at (8,7) (|8–5| + |7–6| = 3, if we plan a multi‐step route).

From our head at (5,6) the only legal moves are:
• UP → (5,7)
• RIGHT → (6,6)
(Down would be (5,5) and LEFT would be (4,6), and both are part of our body.)

Both UP and RIGHT move us closer to the apple at (8,7):
– Moving RIGHT: from (5,6) to (6,6) gives a new Manhattan distance: |8–6| + |7–6| = 2 + 1 = 3.
– Moving UP: from (5,6) to (5,7) gives |8–5| + |7–7| = 3 + 0 = 3.

Either move makes progress, but moving RIGHT directly increases our x value, which is desirable since the target apple is to the east. There aren’t any threats immediately from the enemy snake (whose head is at (1,5) and whose body segments are far away).

Thus, for planning a multi-apple strategy and approaching the apple at (8,7) while keeping safe, the best move for our current turn is to go RIGHT.

Final decision: RIGHT.

Thus, our strategy is to steer toward (8,7) by moving east, and the move RIGHT not only makes progress but sets us up nicely for the subsequent turn.
